exampleContent.title: Fill in the Blanks Examples
exampleContent.description: Learn how to complete sentences using word relationships and context clues
learningPoints: Words in the same family share a common root or base
Different suffixes and prefixes create new related words
Context helps determine which form of the word to use
Understanding word families helps expand vocabulary
Pay attention to grammar rules when forming words

sections.title: Word Family Relationships
sections.description: Learn how root words can be transformed into related words with different meanings

examples.explanation: The word 'reverse' shares the same root as 'reversible'. When something is reversible, it means it can be reversed.
The past participle 'broken' comes from the base verb 'break'.

examples.sentence: A person who {answer} is called a {given}
examples.explanation: A teacher is someone who teaches. The suffix '-er' is added to verbs to create nouns for people who do that action.

sections.title: Suffix and Prefix Patterns
sections.description: Understanding how word parts combine to create new meanings

examples.explanation: Add -s to form the plural of 'tree'.
The prefix 'un-' means 'not', so 'unhappy' means 'not happy'.
Add '-ly' to adjectives to form adverbs that describe how something is done.

sections.title: Possessive Forms
sections.description: Learn how to show ownership using apostrophes

examples.sentence: The {given} has a balloon. It is the {answer} balloon.
examples.explanation: Add 's to show that the balloon belongs to the clown.
examples.rule: For singular nouns, add 's to show possession

examples.sentence: The {given} toys are scattered. These are the {answer} toys.
examples.explanation: For plural nouns not ending in 's', add 's to show possession.

exercises.explanation: Use the adverb 'quickly' to describe how the runner finished the race.

exercises.explanation: The prefix 'un-' creates the opposite meaning, so 'unhappy' means 'not happy'.
